text: The newborn eye is usually 	. Myopic Hypermetropic Emmetropic Astigmatic
explanation:
:
A newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2D to +3D.
The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the eyeball at birth is about 16.5 mm, which is about 70% of the adult size. This reduced axial length causes light to converge behind the retina, leading to

hypermetropia.
Additionally, the corneal diameter at birth is 10 mm. The adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age. The orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adult (45°).
Note: The lacrimal glands are underdeveloped in a newborn and, hence, do not secrete tears.

text: At what age would a child attain full visual acuity? 6 months 1 year 3 years 6 years
explanation:
:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years. Important milestones in visual development are:
At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly.
By the first month of life, the fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months.
By 3 months, binocular vision is established.
By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed.
By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

text: A 45-year-old lady presents with the abnormality as shown below. She is diagnosed with uveal melanoma. What is the embryological origin of the cells involved? Neural ectoderm Mesoderm Surface ectoderm Neural crest
explanation:
:
Uveal melanomas arise from uveal melanocytes. Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes are derived from the neural crest cells.

text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of the eye? The macula is fully developed at birth. The lens grows throughout life. The cornea attains normal diameter by 2 years. Full visual acuity is attained by 6 years of age.
explanation:
:
The macula is fully developed by 4–6 months of age. Apart from the macula, the rest of the retina is fully developed at birth.
Postnatal Development of Eye:
3 Months - Binocular single vision develops.
4-6 Months - Macula fully develops. Fusional reflexes, stereopsis, and accommodation become well developed
6 Months - Fixation, which had started developing in the first month is now complete
2 Years - Cornea develops to the normal adult diameter
6 Years - Visual acuity fully develops and reaches 6/6
The lens, however, continues to grow throughout the life

text: By how many weeks of embryonic development does the optic groove appear? 2 weeks 3 weeks 4 weeks 5 weeks
explanation:
:
The optic groove appears by 3 weeks. By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

text: Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from 	. Surface ectoderm Neural ectoderm Neural crest Mesoderm
explanation:
:
Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from the neural crest.

text: After conception, the canal of Schlemm appears by 	 . 3rd month 4th month 5th month 6th month
explanation:
:

The canal of Schlemm appears by the 4th month after conception.

text: What is the anteroposterior diameter of the adult eyeball? 2.6 cm 2.5 cm 2.4 cm 2.1 cm
explanation:
:
The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the adult eye is 24 mm/2.4 cm.
At birth, the average axial length of the eyeball is 16.5 mm. By 3 years, it grows rapidly to approximately 23 mm. From 3 to 14 years of age, the axial length gradually increases by a further 1 mm, bringing it to the adult size of 24 mm. This overall adjustment in the eye size, including the refractive power, is called emmetropization.

text: A 34-year-old lady comes to the clinic complaining of problems in her vision. On perimetry, a visual field defect as shown below is obtained. Which of the following vessels does not supply the anatomical location of the lesion? Anterior cerebral arter Anterior communicating arter Internal carotid arter Middle cerebral arter
explanation:
:
The image shows bitemporal hemianopia, a defect caused by optic chiasmal lesions. The middle cerebral artery does not supply the optic chiasma.
Blood supply of optic chiasma:
Anterior cerebral artery - dorsal chiasma
Anterior communicating artery - ventral chiasma
Internal carotid artery - ventral chiasma
Superior hypophyseal artery - ventral (branch of internal carotid artery).

text: A college student comes to the OPD for refractive error testing. Her eyes are dilated using tropicamide. Which of the following statements is false about the structure this drug acts on? It is triangular in cross section. There are around 30-40 processes in pars plana and pars plicata Its epithelium is derived from the anterior edge of the optic cup. The pars plana is approximately 4.5 mm from the limbus.
explanation:
:
Tropicamide is a cycloplegic drug that acts on the ciliary body to cause mydriasis for refractory error testing. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that contains 60-70 ciliary processes in

each eye, present on the pars plicata.
The pars plana is 4.5mm from the limbus while the distance between the equator and the limbus is 14mm.
The ciliary epithelium is derived from the optic cup (neuroectoderm) by the continued growth of the outer lip's anterior edge.

text: A 12-year-old girl you examined in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What is the most common site where the condition is seen? Superonasal Inferonasal Superotemporal Inferotemporal
explanation:
:
The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant.
A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types:
Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation.
Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary bod and a part of choroid.
Other embryonic remnants in the eye:
Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid arter
Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid arter
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

text: A child was brought with complaints of decreased vision. Fundus examination shows a developmental anomaly as shown below. What is the cause of this anomaly? Incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure Faulty migration of neural crest cells Exuberant proliferation of glial tissue Abnormal retinal differentiation
explanation:
:
The image shows a coloboma of the optic disc, accompanied by a large chorioretinal coloboma located below the optic disc, which is caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.
This developmental anomaly may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. Coloboma of the optic disc can present in two forms: a minor effect often associated with refractive errors like hypermetropia and astigmatism and a fully developed coloboma that appears as a large inferonasal whitish excavation resembling the optic disc.
Defective vision and superior visual field defects are typically associated with fully developed coloboma. Additionally, this condition may be associated with chorioretinal coloboma, a congenital anomaly where the developing optic cup fails to fuse completely, leading to abnormal choroidal and retinal development.
Note: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the image? Neural ectoderm Mesoderm Surface ectoderm Neural crest
explanation:
:
The lacrimal gland arises from the surface ectoderm.

text: The optic foramen is situated between the: Lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid Lesser wing and body of the sphenoid Greater wing and body of the sphenoid Two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid
explanation:
:
The optic foramen is situated between the two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid.
The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is formed medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa.
The optic canal transmits the optic nerve with its meningeal coverings; the ophthalmic artery, which is below the nerve, is embedded in its dural sheath, and a few twigs from the sympathetic plexus accompanying the artery.

text: During a game, a 26-year-old baseball player is hit in the head by a baseball, which fractures the optic canal. Which of the following pairs of structures is most likely to be damaged? Optic nerve and ophthalmic vein Ophthalmic vein and ophthalmic nerve Ophthalmic artery and optic nerve Ophthalmic nerve and optic nerve
explanation:
:

In the given clinical scenario, a fracture of the optic canal is most likely to damage the ophthalmic artery and optic nerve, as these are the primary structures passing through it.
The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is a short cylindrical structure bounded medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa, serving as a pathway for the aforementioned structures along with its sympathetic plexus.
Optic canal fractures, often associated with basilar skull fractures, can lead to optic neuropathy. The intracanalicular and intracranial portion of the optic nerve is most commonly affected in head trauma.
Note: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bound the superior orbital fissure.

text: The anterior segment of the eye includes all except 	. Anterior chamber Posterior chamber Vitreous Lens
explanation:
:
The anterior segment of the eye does not include vitreous humor as it is a constituent of the posterior segment of the eye.

text: The posterior chamber in the eyeball is filled with 	. Aqueous humor Vitreous humor Lymph Blood
explanation:
:

The posterior chamber of the eyeball is filled with aqueous humor.
The eyeball is divided into anterior and posterior segments. The anterior segment includes the lens and the structures anterior to it, such as the cornea, iris and two aqueous humor-filled spaces:
Anterior chamber: Located between cornea and iris, contains aqueous humor and communicates with the posterior chamber through the pupil.
Posterior chamber: Triangular-shaped space, also contains aqueous humor, bounded anteriorl by the posterior surface of the iris, laterally by the ciliary body, and posteriorly by the lens.
The posterior segment includes all structures located posterior to the lens, comprising of the vitreous humor, retina, choroid and optic disc.

text: Which of the following structures is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle? Check ligament of the medial rectus Superior oblique tendon Check ligament of the lateral rectus Whitnall's ligament
explanation:
:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle.
Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the
fronto-zygomatic suture.
Four structures are attached to it:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus
Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball)
Lateral palpebral ligament
Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis
The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior tarsal plate and the orbital bone.

text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tarsal plates? Tarsal plates are cartilaginous structures. They give structural support to the eyelid. LPS aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate. Their medial and lateral ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments, respectively.
explanation:
:
The tarsal plates are not cartilaginous structures but firm, dense connective tissue (fibrous tissue) plates.
The tarsal plates serve as the structural support of the eyelids. The height of the upper tarsal plate is about 10 mm, and that of the lower tarsal plate is 4 mm. Both plates have a thickness of about 1
mm. The ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments (medial and lateral canthal tendons). The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.
The meibomian glands are located within the tarsus. These are holocrine-secreting sebaceous glands that are not associated with lash follicles.

text: A 55-year-old man is being evaluated for herpes zoster ophthalmicus. On eliciting corneal reflex, there is no response. Which of the following nerves forms the afferent limb of this reflex? Infratrochlear nerve Supratrochlear nerve Supraorbital nerve Long ciliary nerve
explanation:
:
The sensory supply of the cornea comes from the long ciliary nerve (branch of the nasociliary nerve). It forms the afferent limb of the corneal reflex.
The sensory nerve supply of the eye is by the ophthalmic nerve.
Lacrimal nerve- lacrimal gland, conjunctiva, lateral eyelid
Frontal nerve- conjunctiva, eyelid, part of the forehead
Nasociliary nerve
Long ciliary nerve- cornea, ciliary body, iris
Infra-trochlear nerve- conjunctiva, lacrimal sac, caruncle, medial part of the eyelids Corneal sensation is reduced in leprosy and diabetes mellitus (neuropathy).

text: Which intrinsic ocular muscle has a parasympathetic innervation? Superior rectus Superior oblique Sphincter pupillae Dilator pupillae
explanation:
:
The intrinsic ocular muscle supplied by parasympathetic innervation is the sphincter pupillae.
Parasympathetic innervation:
Sphincter pupillae: Short ciliary nerve–Ciliary ganglion
Ciliary muscle–Accessory ganglion
Sympathetic innervation: Dilator pupillae and Muller’s muscle
Motor Supply:
3rd nerve: All extraocular muscles (except the 2 given below)
6th nerve: Lateral rectus (LR6)
4th nerve: Superior oblique (SO4)
7th nerve: Orbicularis oculi

text: What is the thinnest part of the retina? Foveola Fovea centralis Optic disc Ora serrata
explanation:
:
The retina is the thinnest (0.080 mm) at the ora serrata, and thickest, at the foveal rim (0.23,
0.320 mm).
The ora serrata is the serrated junction between the retina and ciliary body.

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images.

Angle alpha () is the angle between the optical axis and visual axis at the nodal point.
Angle lambda ( ) is the angle between the pupillary axis and the line of sight. It is the global tilt offset of the eye when it fixates on a specific target and is a response to the eccentric displaced position of the fovea from the geometrical center of the retina. (Option B)
Angle kappa () is the angle between the visual axis and the pupillary line at the cornea. It is the only angle that can be measured and is of clinical significance. (Option C)

Negative  is seen in pseudoesotropia

Solution to Question 9:
Shortening of 2mm of the axial length of the eyeball will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.
In axial hypermetropia, 1mm shortening of the anteroposterior diameter of the eye results in 3 dioptres of hypermetropia. Therefore, 2-mm shortening will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.
In curvature hypermetropia, a 1mm increase in radius of curvature results in 6 dioptres of hypermetropia.



Solution to Question 10:
The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least confusion.
When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points.
The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval.
F r the given Sturm's conoid,
At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays.
At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line.
At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging.

At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion.
At point E, a vertical oval is formed.
At point F, a vertical straight line is formed
At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

The Stiles–Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays. It is one of the natural mechanisms that decrease aberration in the eye. The rays of light that enter through the center of the pupil have higher sensitivity as compared to those entering from the periphery of the pupil.
Natural mechanisms that decrease aberrations in the human eye:
Cutting-off of the peripheral rays by the iris
The high refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
Stiles–Crawford effect

Solution to Question 16:
Metarhodopsin II is responsible for phototransduction.
It activates transducin member of G proteins. This leads to the closure of Na+ channels and hyperpolarization, thereby inducing phototransduction (signal transduction in the retina).


Solution to Question 17:

Solution to Question 18:
Chromophore regeneration occurs in the retinal pigment epithelial cells. Phototransduction:
Rhodopsin is a G-protein-coupled receptor found in the outer segments of rod photoreceptors.
11-cis-retinal (a chromophore) is covalently bound to opsins via a lysine residue on one of the transmembrane domains.
The receptor is activated by photo-isomerization of prebound 11-cis-retinal t ALL-TRANS-retinal.
Activation of the receptor causes binding and activation of the G protein, transducin, with signal transduction via cGMP phosphodiesterase, resulting in a decrease in the intracellular cGMP levels and closure of the cGMP-gated Na channels.
This causes hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell, which modulates neurotransmitter release at the synapse with bipolar cells.
This entire process triggered by the activation of rhodopsin is phototransduction, which occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors and converts light energy into an electrical signal.
Chromophore regeneration:
All-trans retinAL is converted to all-trans-retinOL.

All-trans-retinOL gets transported by interphotoreceptor retinoid-binding protein (IRBP) to the retinal pigment epithelial cells, where it is reconstituted into the 11-cis retinal isoform.




Solution to Question 19:
The parvocellular pathway gives signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details. LGB: lateral geniculate body
The interlaminar pathway gives signals for color vision to layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex having clusters of cells called blobs.






Solution to Question 20:
Blobs in the primary visual cortex are rich in the enzyme cytochrome oxidase.
Blobs are sections of the visual cortex where groups of neurons that are sensitive to color assemble in cylindrical shapes. They are present in layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex.



Solution to Question 21:
K nio cells are involved in the transmission of color.
The koniocellular pathway is ventral to each parvocellular and magnocellular layer of the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN). K cells are neurochemically and anatomically distinct from M and P cells. They contain calbindin protein, whereas M cells and P cells contain parvalbumin. K1,
K4, and K6 receive ipsilateral retinal inputs, and K3 and K5 receive contralateral retinal inputs. K2 receives both.






Solution to Question 22:
The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm. Theories of color vision:
Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different spectral sensitivities.
Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green).
Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture.






Solution to Question 23:
In deuteranomaly, the perception of green color is defective. It is the most common disorder of color vision.
Monochromacy: Only one of the three primary colors (red, blue, or green) can be appreciated. Dichromacy: Two primary colors are appreciated. (anopia = absent).
Protanopia: Red color is not perceived.
Deuteranopia: Green color is not perceived.
Tritanopia: Blue color is not perceived.
Trichromacy: All the three primary colors are appreciated, but one of them can be defective
(anomaly = defective).
Protanomaly: Red color perception is defective.
Deuteranomaly: Green color perception is defective.
Tritanomaly: Blue color perception is defective.
Achromatopsia: No color perception due to the absence of cones. It may also occur in the lesion of area V4 or V8 of the visual cortex.
